summary: Volkswagen was fined 1 billion euros in a case brought by German prosecutors over the company's prominent role in the diesel emissions cheating scandal.
Daimler agreed to pay an 870 million euro penalty to resolve an investigation by the Stuttgart Public Prosecutor of improper emissions certifications of diesel vehicles.
Audi was fined 800 million euros in a case brought by German prosecutors over the company's role in the diesel emissions cheating scandal.
Volkswagen agreed to pay 830 million euros to settle litigation brought by the Federation of German Consumer Organizations (VZBV) in connection with the company's rigging of diesel emissions tests.
Porsche agreed to pay 535 million euros to settle a case brought by German prosecutors over the company's role in the diesel emissions cheating scandal.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling around 646 million euros on Ilsenburger Grobblech GmbH, thyssenkrupp Steel Europe AG and voestalpine Grobblech GmbH as well as three individuals responsible for exchanging information on and agreeing certain price supplements and surcharges for steel plates in Germany. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Thyssenkrupp disclosed on page 203 of its annual report that it paid 370 million euros: (click here)
UBS agreed to pay 300 million euros to resolve allegations it helped German customers evade taxes.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines amounting to around 280 million euros on the three major German sugar manufacturers--Pfeifer & Langen GmbH & Co.KG, Sudzucker AG, and Nordzucker AG--for concluding anticompetitive agreements on sales areas, quotas and prices. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Sudzucker AG disclosed on page 48 of its 2014/15 Management Report that it paid 195.5 million euros: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling around 646 million euros on Ilsenburger Grobblech GmbH, thyssenkrupp Steel Europe AG and voestalpine Grobblech GmbH as well as three individuals responsible for exchanging information on and agreeing certain price supplements and surcharges for steel plates in Germany. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Ilsenburger Grobblech's parent Salzgitter AG disclosed on page 80 of its annual report that it paid 211 million euros: (click here)
Credit Suisse agreed to pay 150 million euros to settle allegations that it helped clients evade taxes.

In 2014 the Bundeskartellamt imposed fines amounting to 231.2 million Euros against a group of breweries in its proceedings concerning illegal price fixing agreements for beer. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Radeberger initially appealed its fine but in 2018 it agreed to pay 160 million euros: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling approximately 205 million euros on six special steel companies, a trade association and ten individuals for concluding price-fixing agreements and exchanging competitively sensitive information. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but ArcelorMittal disclosed on page 31 of its 2018 annual report that it paid USD$146 million: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 124.5 million euros on four rail manufacturers and suppliers for concluding anticompetitive agreements to the detriment of Deutsche Bahn AG. ThyssenKrupp GfT Gleistechnik GmbH was fined 103 million euros: (click here). That was later revised to 88 million euros.

The public prosecutor's office in Hanover issued a fine totaling EUR 100 million against Continental AG and individual subsidiaries because of a negligent breach of supervisory duties in connection with the supply of engine control units and engine control unit software. The fine, linked to the Dieselgate emissions scandal, related to the business activities of Continental's former powertrain division, which was spun off to form Vitesco Technologies in 2021.
Bosch agreed to pay 90 million euros to settle a case brought by German prosecutors over the company's role in the diesel emissions cheating scandal.
Airbus agreed to pay over 80 million euros to resolve a bribery investigation by the Munch Public Prosecutor.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 154 million euros against seven producers of crop protection products. The agency did not specify how much each company would pay, but coverage of BayWa's unsuccessful challenge to the penalty reported that its share was 68 million euros: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling around 646 million euros on Ilsenburger Grobblech GmbH, thyssenkrupp Steel Europe AG and voestalpine Grobblech GmbH as well as three individuals responsible for exchanging information on and agreeing certain price supplements and surcharges for steel plates in Germany. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but voestalpine Grobblech's parent voestalpine AG disclosed on page 167 of its annual report that it paid 65.5 million euros: (click here)
Julius Baer agreed to pay 50 million euros to resolve allegations it helped German clients evade taxes.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 115 euros million on five leading manufacturers of ophthalmic lenses in Germany for their involvement in cartel agreements. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Essilor disclosed on page 127 of its 2010 annual report that it was fined 50 million euros: (click here)

In August 2010 the Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totaling approximately 91 million euros against Alstom Power Systems GmbH and against two former directors for entering in agreements on customer allocation and on quotas and prices for utility steam generators. The company appealed, and in October 2011 the fine was reduced to 42 million euros.

In 2014 the Bundeskartellamt imposed fines amounting to 231.2 million Euros against a group of breweries in its proceedings concerning illegal price fixing agreements for beer: (click here). The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Carlsberg Deutschland's parent disclosed on page 43 of its 2014 Financial Statement that its fine was 62 million euros: (click here). Carlsberg appealed the fine. In 2023 a court changed the penalty to 50 million euros.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling around 100 million euros on Bayerische Motoren Werke AG, Daimler AG and Volkswagen AG for anticompetitive practices in the purchase of long steel products. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but there were numerous reports that VW's share was 48.7 million: (click here)

The Federal Financial Supervisory Authority (BaFin) imposed an administrative fine of 45 million euros on J.P. Morgan SE, domiciled in Frankfurt am Main, for shortcomings in the company's money laundering prevention. The credit institution culpably breached its supervisory obligations regarding internal processes for the submission of suspicious transaction reports. As a result of these procedural shortcomings, in the period from 4 October 2021 to 30 September 2022, J.P. Morgan SE systemically failed to submit suspicious transaction reports without undue delay.

enforcing_agency: Federal Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information-BFDI
summary: A fine of 15 million euros was imposed because Vodafone GmbH had not adequately checked and monitored partner agencies working for it in terms of data protection law ( Article 28 ( 1 ) sentence 1 GDPR ). A further fine of 30 million euros was imposed for security flaws in the authentication process when using the MeinVodafone online portal in conjunction with the Vodafone hotline. The discovered authentication vulnerabilities allowed, among other things, unauthorized third parties to access eSIM profiles.
A susidiary of Rheinmetall agreed to pay a fine to end a criminal investigation of suspected bribery payments during arms deals in Greece.

company_name: H&M Hennes & Mauritz Online Shop A.B. & Co KG
enforcing_agency: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
summary: The Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection, acting on behalf of the EDPB, fined H&M more than 35 million euros for improperly collecting and storing information about the health of employees and other personal information.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed a fine amounting to EUR 30 million on IVECO Magirus Brandschutztechnik GmbH, Ulm. The company was accused of having implemented illegal price-fixing and quota agreements together with three other manufacturers of fire-fighting vehicles and of having carved up the German market for fire-fighting vehicles among themselves since at least 2001.
Sanofi was fined in connection with a bribery scandal.

On February 4, 2021 the Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 35 million euros on two German steel forging subsidiaries of India's Bharat Forge Limited and an unaffiliated Germany company for their involvement in an anti-competitive exchange of information. On December 23, 2020 the Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 175 million euros on five aluminium forging companies, including Bharat Forge Aluminiumtechnik GmbH, accused of engaging in illegal anti-competitive agreements. In neither case did the agency specify how much any of the individual companies would pay, but Bharat Forge disclosed it had paid the eqivalent of about 31 million euros in the two cases combined: (click here)

The Dusseldorf Higher Regional Court imposed a fine of 30 million euros against Dirk Rossmann GmbH, increasing a peanlty imposed by the Bundeskartellamt in 2015 for vertical price fixing in the sale of roasted coffee.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 75 million euros on five manufacturers of automotive acoustic components for anti-competitive practices. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Autoneum disclosed on page 3 of its 2015 annual report that it paid 31.5 million euros: (click here)
The Bundeskartellamt imposed a fine of EUR 23.8 million on VK Muhlen AG on account of its involvement in illegal agreements in the sale of flour.
The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines amounting to approximately EUR 24 million on Reckitt Benckiser Deutschland GmbH for participating in illegal price agreements relating to dishwasher detergent.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling around 100 million euros on Bayerische Motoren Werke AG, Daimler AG and Volkswagen AG for anticompetitive practices in the purchase of long steel products. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. BWM disclosed on page 13 of its 2019 annual report that it paid 28 million euros: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt fined Kraft Foods Deutschland GmbH 21.7 million for participation in phone calls with Alfred Ritter GmbH & Co. KG which involved discussions of planned price increases for chocolate bars.

German prosecutors fined asset manager DWS 25 million euros after a lengthy probe found the firm guilty of greenwashing, or making misleading statements about the environmental and social credentials of its investment products.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling around 100 million euros on Bayerische Motoren Werke AG, Daimler AG and Volkswagen AG for anticompetitive practices in the purchase of long steel products. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but there were numerous reports that Daimler's share was 23.5 million: (click here)
The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 20 million euros on Nestle Deutschland AG for participating in an illegal exchange of competition-relevant information.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed a fine of 17.5 million euros against Iveco Magirus Brandschutztechnik GmbH in Ulm for its involvement in anti-competitive agreements on the manufacture of fire engines equipped with turntable ladders.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling EUR 38 million on three manufacturers of consumer goods on account of the illegal exchange of competition relevant information. The agency did not announce how much each company would pay, but in an SEC filing Kraft Foods said its fine was 18 million Euros: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling EUR 38 million on three manufacturers of consumer goods--Kraft Foods Deutschland, Unilever Deutschland and a smaller company-- on account of the illegal exchange of competition relevant information. The agency did not announce how much each company would pay, but in an SEC filing Kraft Foods said its fine was 18 million Euros. Here we assume Unilever paid the same amount.

The sanction was based on violations of Section 80 Paragraph 1 Sentence 2 Number 1 of the Securities Trading Act ( WpHG ) and Section 130 Paragraph 1 of the Administrative Offenses Act ( OWiG ) in conjunction with Section 83 Paragraph 3 Sentence 1 of the WpHG as well as Section 22 of the Payment Accounts Act ( ZKG ) and Section 23 Paragraph 1 of the ZKG .

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 18.3 million euros on retailers EDEKA Handelsgesellschaft Nord mbH and EDEKA Handelsgesellschaft Hessenring mbH, for involvement in price fixing agreements on the shop prices for beer products.
Commerzbank agreed to pay 17 million euros to resolve allegations its subsidiaries in Luxembourg helped wealthy German clients stash assets in shell companies in Panama to evade German taxes.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 115 euros million on five leading manufacturers of ophthalmic lenses in Germany for their involvement in cartel agreements. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Essilor disclosed on page 127 of its 2010 annual report that it was fined 50 million euros: (click here). Hoya did not disclose its share. Here we assume it was one-fourth of the remainder, or about 15 million euros.
The Bundeskartellamt fined Tempur Deutschland GmbH 15.5 million euros for imposing resale price maintenance on retailers selling its products.
Deutsche Bank agreed to pay 15 million euros to resolve a criminal investigation by the Frankfurt Public Prosecutor of abetting tax evasion and money laundering.

The sanction was based on a violation of Section 80 Paragraph 2 Sentence 3 Numbers 1 and 2 of the Securities Trading Act ( WpHG ). Citigroup Global Markets Europe AG , as a securities services company that conducts algorithmic trading, did not have systems and risk controls in place to ensure that its trading systems are subject to appropriate trading thresholds and trading limits and that it avoids the transmission of erroneous orders which could cause or contribute to market disruptions.
Deutsche Borse was penalized by a German prosecutor for insider trading that allegedly took place before its plan to merge wit the London Stock Exchange Group became public.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines amounting to a total of 24.3 million Euros on four manufacturers of power transformers. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but ABB disclosed on page 111 of its 2012 annual report that it paid 8.7 million euros: (click here)

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 110 million euros against eleven technical building service providers for colluding on bids for major contracts. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share of the total.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 110 million euros against eleven technical building service providers for colluding on bids for major contracts. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share of the total.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 110 million euros against eleven technical building service providers for colluding on bids for major contracts. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share of the total.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 110 million euros against eleven technical building service providers for colluding on bids for major contracts. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share of the total.

As a supervised contributor, Deutsche Bank AG at times did not have in place effective preventive systems, controls and policies to ensure the integrity and reliability of all contributions of input data to the administrator.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 39 million Euros on six manufacturers of branded drugstore products for engaging in anti-competitive information exchanges. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share.

company_name: GlaxoSmithKline Consumer Healthcare GmbH & Co. KG
summary: The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 39 million Euros on six manufacturers of branded drugstore products for engaging in anti-competitive information exchanges. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 39 million Euros on six manufacturers of branded drugstore products for engaging in anti-competitive information exchanges. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share.

company_name: Gillette Gruppe Deutschland GmbH & Co. oHG
summary: The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 39 million Euros on six manufacturers of branded drugstore products for engaging in anti-competitive information exchanges. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines of 39 million Euros on six manufacturers of branded drugstore products for engaging in anti-competitive information exchanges. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 12.5 million euros against Hochtief Solutions AG and Dillinger Huttenwerke for illegal agreements within the context of award procedures. The agency did not announce how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid half of the total.

company_name: TSTG Schienen Technik GmbH & Co. KG
summary: The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 124.5 million euros on four rail manufacturers and suppliers for concluding anticompetitive agreements to the detriment of Deutsche Bahn AG. TSTG Schienen Technik GmbH & Co. KG was fined 4.5 million euros.

company_name: Kraft Foods Ausser Haus Service GmbH
summary: The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totaling approximnately EUR 30 million on eight coffee roasters on grounds of price fixing in the so-called out-of-house market (supply of bulk customers). The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Kraft Foods disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it paid 4.66 million: (click here)
BaFin fined the bank for failing to send out voting rights notifications in a timely manner.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling 124.5 million euros on four rail manufacturers and suppliers for concluding anticompetitive agreements to the detriment of Deutsche Bahn AG. voestalpine BWG GmbH & Co. KG was fined 4 million euros.

BaFin fined BlackRock for distributing notifications regarding voting rights held and financial instruments incorrectly or late, thereby violating the provisions of the Securities Trading Act (Sections 21, 22, 25). The incorrect or delayed notifications were due to incorrect assessments of the German notification obligations and affected a large number of large German share issuers.

BaFin imposed an administrative fine amounting to EUR 3 million on ABN AMRO Bank N.V.'s Frankfurt branch because the branch's management did not have appropriate access to the Compliance Report for the 2019 financial year.

The Federal Cartel Office imposed a fine of EUR 2.79 million on Strabag AG for illegal agreements in the context of tender rigging in connection with the award of a construction contract for the renovation of the Zoo Bridge in Cologne at the beginning of 2017.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling approximately nine million euros on two manufacturers of instant cappuccino--Kraft Foods Deutschland GmbH and Kruger GmbH & Co. Kommanditgesellschaft--for having agreed on price increases. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Kraft Food disclosed in its 10-K filing for 2011 that it paid 2.2 million euros: (click here)
Migros agreed to pay over 2 million euros to resolve allegations that it helping banking customers evade taxes.

The Cologne public prosecutor's office and DB Schenker agreed to terminate an investigation into unexplained payments for logistics services provided in Russia. At the public prosecutor's request, a fine of 2 million euros was imposed on DB Schenker's Russian entity for breaches of the law between 2010 and mid-2012.
BaFin fined the bank for failing to send out voting rights notifications in a timely manner.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed a fine amounting to 1.43 million euros on Gaul GmbH, a manufacturer of asphalt mixes, for participating in a cartel agreement which involved prices, sales areas, customers and quotas for the supply of construction companies in the Rhine-Main area between 2005 and 2013.

The Federal Financial Supervisory Authority ( BaFin ) imposed two fines of EUR 375,000 and EUR 1,075,000 on Commerzbank AG - also as the universal successor to comdirect Bank AG - with a legally binding decision dated March 11, 2024 on the basis of Section 130 Paragraph 1 of the Act on Administrative Offenses (OWiG) in conjunction with Section 56 Paragraph 1 Sentence 1 No. 3, Section 56 Paragraph 1 Sentence 1 No. 20, Section 56 Paragraph 1 No. 32 GwG, Section 56 Paragraph 1 No. 34 GwG and Section 56 Paragraph 1 No. 35 GwG of the Act on the Tracing of Proceeds from Serious Crimes (Money Laundering Act - GwG).
BaFin fined the company for failing to comply with the requirement to publish inside information in a timely fashion.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines amounting to a total of 24.3 million Euros on four manufacturers of power transformers. The Bundeskartellamt did not specify how much each company would pay, but Siemens disclosed on page 194 of its 2012 annual report that it "agreed to pay a fine in the single-digit EUR million range": (click here). Here we use a figure of 1 million euros to represent the minimum amount it paid.

BaFin imposed an administrative fine amounting to 1,000,000 euros on Landesbank Berlin AG on grounds that the bank had violated the Market Abuse Regulation (MAR) by unlawfully disclosing inside information.

enforcing_agency: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
summary: The Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection, acting on behalf of the EDPB, fined Vattenfall more than 900,000 euros for violating data regulations when checking applications for new-customer discounts for electricity supply contracts.

As an investment services provider, BNP Paribas S.A. Niederlassung Deutschland did not provide its clients with information on all costs and associated charges relating to specific financial instruments in good time in accordance with the requirements.
BaFin fined the company for failing to send out voting rights notifications in a timely manner.
BaFin fined the company for failing to send out voting rights notifications in a timely manner.
BaFin fined Barclays for failing to distribute voting rights notifications within the prescribed period.
BaFin fined Covestro for failing to publish a notification that it had reached a relevant threshold in respect of its own shares within the prescribed period.
BaFin fined the company for failing to comply with the requirement to publish inside information in a timely fashion.

After being fined 12 million euros by German environmental regulators for failure to comply with regulations on taking back and recycling automobile batteries, the company appealed and eventually got the penalty reduced to 600,000 euros.
The sanction related to a breach of the first subparagraph of Article 17 (1) of the Market Abuse Regulation (MAR). MTU Aero Engines AG failed to publish inside information without undue delay.
The German arm of EY was fined 500,000 for breach of professional duty in auditing the financial processor Wirecard AG, which became insolvent amid a financial scandal.
Landesbank Baden-Wurttemberg was fined for failing to notify BaFin without delay that it had reasonable suspicion that an order in a financial instrument constituted insider dealing.
AKBANK AG was found to have failed to implement effective policies, systems, and procedures for detecting and reporting suspicious orders and transactions.
BaFin fined Bayer for failing to distribute voting rights notifications within the prescribed period.
BaFin fined the company for failing to comply with the requirement to publish inside information in a timely fashion.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed fines totalling approximately 2.4 million Euro on eight manufacturers of automatic door systems on account of several illegal agreements. The agency did not say how much each company would pay. Here we assume they each paid an equal share.
BaFin fined the company for failing to send out voting rights notifications in a timely manner.
BaFin fined the company for failing to comply with the requirement to publish inside information in a timely fashion.
The Bundeskartellamt imposed a fine of 225,000 euros against SodaStream GmbH for improper restrictions on CO2 cartridge refills.
Energi Danmark was fined for manipulation of the wholesale electricity market.

Delivery Hero was fined for failure to respect the rights of data subjects, such as the right to information about the processing of their own data, the right to have their data deleted, and the right to object.

enforcing_agency: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
summary: Google was fined for systematic, illegal collection of personal data while it was creating the Street View mapping service.
BaFin fined the bank for delays in the submission of suspicious activity reports.
The Bundesnetzagentur imposed a fine of EUR 150,000 on Uniper Global Commodities SE in response to a case of gas market manipulation.
BaFin fined the company for failing to comply with the requirement to publish inside information in a timely fashion.

The Bundeskartellamt imposed a fine of 130,000 euros on LEGO GmbH for enforcing vertical resale price maintenance in the sale of its so-called highlight articles. Those affected were retailers in northern and eastern Germany who in 2012 and 2013 were forced by sales representatives of LEGO GmbH to raise their retail prices.

company_name: BNP Paribas Asset Management Holding S.A.
summary: BaFin fined the company for failing to send out voting rights notifications in a timely manner.

BaFin imposed a fine of 120,000 euros on the Bank of China Limited's Frankfurt am Main branch for exceeding the large exposure limit, thus violating the requirements of the European Capital Adequacy Regulation.

The sanction was based on a violation of Section 115 Paragraph 1 Sentence 1 in conjunction with Section 115 Paragraph 2 Number 3 of the Securities Trading Act ( WpHG ). Capital One AG did not make the half-yearly financial report for the 2018 financial year available to the public in a timely manner.

enforcing_agency: Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection and Freedom of Information
summary: The Hamburg Commissioner for Data Protection, acting on behalf of the EDPB, fined Facebook for not reporting that it had changed its data protection officer.

The financial regulator BaFin has imposed a fine of 50,000 euros on Deutsche Bank AG . The reason: The regulator had found that the institute had made false statements to it about a serious customer-relevant IT security incident in its payment services in 2023. The bank had also informed BaFin significantly late.

By decision of January 8, 2024, the Federal Financial Supervisory Authority ( BaFin ) imposed ten fines totaling EUR 22,000 on Scania Finance Deutschland GmbH on the basis of Section 56 Paragraph 2 Number 1 Letter f) of the German Banking Act (Kreditwesengesetz - KWG ).

BaFin took action against Societe Generale SA , Frankfurt am Main branch, in a decision dated April 7, 2020 on the basis of Section 56 ( 1) No. 7 of the Money Laundering Act ( GwG ) in conjunction with. d. F. _ d. Art. 10 G. v. July 10, 2018 ( Federal Law Gazette I p. 1102) imposed a fine of 12,500 euros.

BaFin imposed four fines totaling 11,000 euros on Tesla Financial Service GmbH. The fines were based on several violations of the German Banking Act. The company had not reported the departure of a managing director in a timely, correct or complete manner.
